title: How to Dry Sprouts

steps.headline: Test your oven to make sure it can maintain a temperature of 140°F (60°C).
steps.description: A gas oven might not be able to maintain such a low temperature, but it could work by using only the pilot light while an electric oven will need only the bottom element. You may have to disconnect the broiler.

steps.headline: Place an accurate thermometer in the rear of the oven, and make sure it is easily visible.
Arrange the sprouts in a single layer on wire cooling racks covered with cheesecloth.
steps.description: Place the racks on baking trays that allow at least 2 inches (5.1 cm) of space between the trays and the oven wall.

steps.headline: Place the trays in the oven, spacing them 2.5 inches (6.4 cm) apart and allowing 3 inches (7.6 cm) of air space between the tray and the top of the oven.
Prop the oven door open about 4 inches (10.2 cm), and set up a small rotating fan near the open door to circulate the air.
steps.description: Be sure to place the fan so that it cannot blow out the pilot light on a gas stove.

steps.headline: Check the drying sprouts frequently, at least every 15 minutes, and switch trays every 30 minutes, turning the sprouts when you switch the trays.
steps.description: Sprouts should dry in 6 to 8 hours, depending on humidity.

steps.headline: Maintain the oven temperature at the 140°F (60°C) level for at least the first hour of drying.
steps.description: After that, lower it to 120°F (49°F) for the remainder of the drying time. This is to avoid the danger of burning which rises as the moisture content of the sprouts is lowered.

steps.headline: Place wooden blocks on a tabletop.
steps.description: These will hold up your first screen of drying sprouts to ensure there is room for air to circulate beneath the screen and that the screen doesn't touch the tabletop.

steps.headline: Cover a screen with cheesecloth and place on the blocks.
Arrange the sprouts as you did for oven drying.
steps.description: Stack the screens as high as you wish, leaving at least 2.5 inches (6.4 cm) of space between layers.

steps.headline: Cover the top layer of sprouts with cheesecloth to discourage birds and insects.
Allow sprouts to dry for 3 days.
Store your dried sprouts in food-safe containers away from direct sunlight.
steps.description: Check them frequently, and if you see any sign on condensation in the jars, the sprouts need to go back for further drying. Dispose of dried sprouts that show any signs of mold.

text: Oven Drying Sprouts Test your oven to make sure it can maintain a temperature of 140°F (60°C). A gas oven might not be able to maintain such a low temperature, but it could work by using only the pilot light while an electric oven will need only the bottom element. You may have to disconnect the broiler. Place an accurate thermometer in the rear of the oven, and make sure it is easily visible. Set the oven thermostat to 140°F (60°C). Arrange the sprouts in a single layer on wire cooling racks covered with cheesecloth. Place the racks on baking trays that allow at least 2 inches (5.1 cm) of space between the trays and the oven wall. Place the trays in the oven, spacing them 2.5 inches (6.4 cm) apart and allowing 3 inches (7.6 cm) of air space between the tray and the top of the oven.  Prop the oven door open about 4 inches (10.2 cm), and set up a small rotating fan near the open door to circulate the air. Be sure to place the fan so that it cannot blow out the pilot light on a gas stove. Check the drying sprouts frequently, at least every 15 minutes, and switch trays every 30 minutes, turning the sprouts when you switch the trays. Sprouts should dry in 6 to 8 hours, depending on humidity. Maintain the oven temperature at the 140°F (60°C) level for at least the first hour of drying. After that, lower it to 120°F (49°F) for the remainder of the drying time. This is to avoid the danger of burning which rises as the moisture content of the sprouts is lowered. Sun Drying Sprouts Place wooden blocks on a tabletop. These will hold up your first screen of drying sprouts to ensure there is room for air to circulate beneath the screen and that the screen doesn't touch the tabletop. Cover a screen with cheesecloth and place on the blocks.  Arrange the sprouts as you did for oven drying. Stack the screens as high as you wish, leaving at least 2.5 inches (6.4 cm) of space between layers. Cover the top layer of sprouts with cheesecloth to discourage birds and insects.  Allow sprouts to dry for 3 days.  Store your dried sprouts in food-safe containers away from direct sunlight. Check them frequently, and if you see any sign on condensation in the jars, the sprouts need to go back for further drying. Dispose of dried sprouts that show any signs of mold.
